description: 1966 FORD MUSTANG CONVERTIBLE,

Silver Mist Blue, AT, P/Steering, Pony Interior, P/T, 5 New Tires, Custom Cassette Radio, Style Steel Wheels with rings & Red Centers, Wood Grain Interior Panel & Glove Box. Restored $25,000. 316-634-2064 -
[Email Seller]
A 1966 Ford Mustang with plenty of slick black, bright chrome, and upgraded V8 power.  Oh yeah, you were already interested in this one before you saw the affordable price.

This coupe was restored around 2013, and that's when the slick black was added to this pony.  A solid investment and the more modern application is why it has such a nice hard shine.  Not only does it look aggressive, but also it's the perfect color to help really appreciate the bright work.  Thin form-hugging bumpers, pony corral grille, rear fender inserts, and all that trim around the glass just seem to pop a bit brighter on this one.  The themes of aggression and shine seem to come together perfectly on the classic Cragar SS wheels.

Inside the dark horse theme continues with the black interior.  You get all the things you love about a first-generation Mustang, like the bucket seats, floor shifter, and the sporty '66 round gauge package.  The wood-rimmed steering wheel just looks like it's calling out to you from within the darkness.  Plus, this one has been subtly upgraded for more modern comfort with a cup holder center console and a retro-style AM/FM cassette stereo.

When you look under the hood, there is a lot of extra power radiating from within the dark engine bay.  Rebuilt only about 500 miles ago, the whole presentation of the motor is bright and fresh.  Plus, you're looking at 302 cubic-inch V8 – larger than anything offered in the '66 Mustang.  And the upgrades don't end there.  It inhales deeply from an Edelbrock four-barrel carburetor, and it exhales with authority as headers add even more power before feeding the glasspack-style exhaust exiting below the car.  So you get strong power and serious growl from this classic Mustang.  To keep the performance focused on the road, you also have upgrades like sub-frame braces and traction bars.  Plus, with the three-speed automatic transmission and power brakes, this extra-power pony is also set up to be a fine cruiser.
When a great total package like this is available for such an obtainable price, you know this is one of the hottest deals going.  Don't miss out, call today!

This awesome 1964.5 Ford Mustang is for sale in our Louisville KY showroom. Lee Iacocca was Ford"??s General Manager and the brains behind the Mustang. He titled the project T-5 and was originally supposed to be a 2-seat roadster but after being reminded of the baby birds dismal numbers they quickly reconsidered. With a new design commissioned the Mustang was born. Released in April of 1964 the first run Mustangs such as this one is called 64.5"??s. Built on 4/23/64 this example has been meticulously maintained over the years and still has less than 100k original miles. The exterior has been repainted back to the original Wimbledon White using the correct lacquer paint which gives it that factory original look. The black vinyl top is original to the car and looks great for being 54 years old. Under the hood is the original 260 Challenger V8 that still runs like a top. With the generator still in place as well as the single master cylinder this exactly what should it be. The Cruise-o-Matic transmission is original to the car and shifts as it should. The interior is black vinyl with the center console being original to the car as well. The AM radio is also original to the car and is in working order if you can find an AM station still. Open the trunk and an original style speckled trunk mat is sure to catch your eye. The spare tire has no cover which is correct for the 64.5"??s as well. With the car being owned by 2 individuals in the last 28 years and given its originality this one is sure to make any Mustang enthusiast a very happy person. Options on this 1964.5 Ford Mustang include AM Radio Power Steering Seat Belts Bias Ply Tires Hubcaps Vinyl Interior and a Numbers Matching Engine. Located in our Louisville Showroom this 1964.5 Ford Mustang can be seen in greater detail including 100+ HD pictures and videos at www.GatewayClassicCars.com. 1965 Ford Mustang Convertible | Ardell Brown Classic Carswww.ardellscars.com/1965-ford-mustang-convertible-3/This 1965 Ford Mustang Convertible has:Motor: 6 CylinderTransmission: AutomaticExterior Color: Red with a Black Convertible TopInterior Color: BlackTheFord Mustangwas manufactured by Ford from March 1964 until 1973. The introduction of the Mustang created a new class of automobile known as the pony car. The Mustangs styling, with its long hood and short deck, proved wildly popular and inspired a host of competition.The standard interior features of the 1965 Mustang included adjustable driver and passenger bucket seats, an AM radio, and a floor mounted shifter in a variety of color options.

A value-priced icon like the 1965 Ford Mustang is already enticing.  But as you dig deeper into this one, you can see someone invested nicely in retaining much of its factory-correct appearance while also adding some worthwhile upgrades.

First-year Mustangs always look great in code-M Wimbledon White.  In fact, it was the color of the first Mustang sold, and so it makes it extra nice to have it the factory-correct on this one.  But what really attracts you to this is the level of gloss and shine that comes from a quality respray.  The extra luster of the paint helps to highlight the straightness of the sheetmetal as well as go nicely with the mirror-like quality of the bumpers and all the vivid trim.  More than just bright, this has a little extra performance attitude with additions like the American Racing Torq Thrust wheels and the red triple rocker stripe.

We know why they added the red stripes on the exterior.  Not only does it look sporty, but it also gives you a nice preview of the interior.  This factory-correct hue looks especially rich, which tells you there have been plenty of nice investments here.  Plush carpeting, solid door panels, and taut red vinyl on the bucket seats make this very inviting.  The thin and grippy three-spoke steering wheel has the perfect vintage feeling, and the ultra-wide speedometer is a favorite these days.  And the atmosphere is so authentic, that when they upgraded to an AM/FM radio w/digital tuner, they used one with a retro appearance to make sure nothing spoils the vintage atmosphere.

Under the hood, this C-code Mustang still retains its proper 289 cubic-inch V8 setup.  Of course, the bright air topper, valve covers, alternator, and much more let you know there was an investment in plenty of flair.  More importantly, the newer belts, wires, and hoses also tell you money was spent on keeping it a strong runner, too.  And the undercarriage photos reveal that the investment in this one was over every inch.  So as And as you look at the clean underside with newer bushings and stainless dual exhaust, you understand that this is one of the most solid cruising coupes around.  That's why it also has good driving features like power steering and a three-speed automatic transmission.
This is the first-year Mustang that gets it right, and it's all offered for an affordable price.  That makes it an irresistible deal that will be moving fast.  Don't miss your chance, call today!

1965 Ford Mustang Convertible | Ardell Brown Classic Carswww.ardellscars.com/1965-ford-mustang-convertible/This early 1965 convertible Mustang is powered by the "D" code 289 4V engine, and automatic transmission. It is presented in Rangoon Red and is equipped with a power convertible top with a rear glass window, power disc brakes, power steering, factory air conditioning, wood grain console, and original radio is in the trunk.The standard interior features of the 1965 Mustang included adjustable driver and passenger bucket seats, an AM radio, and a floor mounted shifter in a variety of color options. Ford added additional interior options during the 1965 model year. The Interior Decor Group was popularly known as "Pony Interior" due to the addition of embossed running ponies on the seat fronts, and also included integral armrests, woodgrain appliqu accents, and a round gauge cluster that would replace the standard Falcon instrumentation. Also available were sun visors, a (mechanical) remote-operated mirror, a floor console, and a bench seat. Ford later offered an under-dash air-conditioning unit, and discontinued the vinyl with cloth insert seat option, offered only in early 1965 models.

Even the executives at Ford couldn't have anticipated the overwhelmingly enthusiastic response when the first Mustangs rolled out. Their prized project combined the sensibilities of a sports car with the convenience of seating for four, and the result was such a success that the Mustang carved out an entirely new niche on the automotive landscape - the Pony Car. This 1964 1/2 Ford Mustang convertible was there from the beginning of all that euphoria and now, more than a half century later, it's ready to provide plenty of enjoyment on the road to go along with its direct link to that pivotal time.

Clad in its original shade of Pagoda green that sits underneath a very solid clearcoat, this Mustang provides visual evidence as to why Ford scored such a decided victory. It's compact, yet not cramped ... sporty, yet not at all ostentatious. Its long hood and short deck lid became a hallmark of the classic muscle cars that would follow, but at the time of its release, it was a design that boldly defied the norm. The finishing touches on this Pony have all been carefully looked after, so you'll find its bumpers both fore and aft sitting appropriately level and sporting clean chrome, its body alignment impressively tight and even, and its trim - from headlight to taillight casings - all representing well. Should you find yourself out on the road enjoying an open-air motoring session and the skies above you turn dark, there's no need to worry - the power black convertible top is in fine condition and raises easily into place to protect you from inclement weather.

There's a very clean black vinyl interior sitting inside the doors and, from the looks of things, it's been well sheltered to keep it out of reach of the sun's harmful influence, so its upgraded Pony furnishings all look great. The low-backed bucket seats up front don't appear to have seen much use, and an expanse of clean black carpeting, punctuated by Pony floor mats up front, sits just underneath. Despite the Mustang's modest size, you'll find an unexpected amount of legroom in back. The dash area looks great, even for a restored classic. The instrument cluster is occupied by a crystal-clear speedometer and a pair of gauges to each side that sport very fresh looking silver frames, joined by a pair of aftermarket oil and water temperature gauges just below. An underdash air conditioning system has been added with an upgraded compressor running on R134a. And in back, the trunk area looks straight and the signature Ford plaid lining leaves enough exposed steel to see that the trunk floors and inner wheelhouses are well aligned and solid.

You'll find a very clean engine compartment underneath the hood, with a smooth-running 260-cubic inch V8 sitting front and center with a chrome air cleaner on top, surrounded by fresh-looking hoses, belts and clean components. You can read every word on the oil filter sitting below - a strong indication that the gaskets just above are fresh and doing their job. The engine pairs with a 3-speed automatic C4 renowned for its durability to make for a low-effort and dependable drive train. When this Mustang debuted, front disc brakes weren't a given, but they're on board here to provide fade-resistant braking. A look underneath will reveal a reassuringly sturdy undercarriage with new-looking floor pans, suspension components and dual exhaust system. This Ford classic sits on a set of 15'' stock Mustang rims outfitted with Arizonian Silver Edition III tires.
It's the car that started an automotive movement, and you don't often find examples as clean as this 1965 Ford Mustang convertible. Call today!

We are pleased to present this 1965  Pink Mustang Coupe with the original drivetrain. In 1964, Ford presented the Playboy Playmate of the Year with a convertible Mustang with a color code WT9301 or Playmate Pink. In 1965, this color was a special order option that was produced in Ford's San Jose, California assembly plant. On a true Playmate Pink Mustang, the door VIN plate will be missing a paint code and instead there will be a DSO (District Sales Office) number which indicates the car was special-ordered by the dealer.  This Mustang fits that criteria.  There is no official data on the number produced, but according to our limited research, we believe there was less than 100 vehicles with this color. Although this vehicle did get repainted over 10 years ago, they did an excellent job on the body that is in excellent condition.  Other than the very rare color, this vehicle has the original 289 V8 with a 2-barrel carburetor and the original C4 three speed automatic transmission, power steering, power brakes and original AM radio. The interior is restored to original white with black trim and looks fantastic. We can arrange shipping to your location. If you have any questions, please contact Savannah Classic Cars 912-235-2347 (no texts).
